column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0681] FIGS. 64-66 depict use of the devices incorporating a sensor for collecting biometric data.
#Text=FIG. 64 shows an embodiment 6400 of the capture of a two-stage palm print.
#Text=FIG. 65 shows collection 6500 using a fingertip tap.
#Text=FIG. 66 demonstrates an embodiment 6600 of a slap and roll print being collected.
#Text=[0682] The discussion above pertains to methods of gathering biometric data, such as fingerprints or palm prints using a platen or touch screen, as shown in FIGS. 66 and 62-66.
#Text=This disclosure also includes methods and systems for touchless or contactless fingerprinting using polarized light.
#Text=In one embodiment, fingerprints may be taken by persons using a polarized light source and retrieving images of the fingerprints using reflected polarized light in two planes.

#Text=In another embodiment, fingerprints may be taken by persons using a light source and retrieving images of the fingerprints using multispectral processing, e.g., using two imagers at two different locations with different inputs.
#Text=The different inputs may be caused by using different filters or different sensors/imagers.
#Text=Applications of this technology may include biometric checks of unknown persons or subjects in which the safety of the persons doing the checking may be at issue.
#Text=[0683] In this method, an unknown person or subject may approach a checkpoint, for example, to be allowed further travel to his or her destination.
#Text=As depicted in the system 6700 shown in FIG. 67, the person P and an appropriate body part, such as a hand, a palm P, or other part, are illuminated by a source of polarized light 6701.

#Text=As is well known to those with skill in optical arts, the source of polarized light may simply be a lamp or other source of illumination with a polarizing filter to emit light that is polarized in one plane.
#Text=The light travels to the person in an area which has been specified for non-contact fingerprinting, so that the polarized light impinges on the fingers or other body part of the person P.
#Text=The incident polarized light is then reflected from the fingers or other body part and passes in all directions from the person.
#Text=Two imagers or cameras 6704 receive the reflected light after the light has passed through optical elements such as a lens 6702 and a polarizing filter 6703.
#Text=The cameras or imagers may be mounted on the augmented reality glasses, as discussed above with respect to FIG. 8F.
#Text=[0684] The light then passes from palm or finger or fingers of the person of interest to two different polarizing filters 6704a, 6704b and then to the imagers or cameras 6705.

#Text=Light which has passed through the polarizing filters may have a 90.degree. orientation difference (horizontal and vertical) or other orientation difference, such as 30.degree., 45.degree., 60.degree. or 120.degree..
#Text=The cameras may be digital cameras with appropriate digital imaging sensors to convert the incident light into appropriate signals.
#Text=The signals are then processed by appropriate processing circuitry 6706, such as digital signal processors.
#Text=The signals may then be combined in a conventional manner, such as by a digital microprocessor with memory 6707.
#Text=The digital processor with appropriate memory is programmed to produce data suitable for an image of a palm, fingerprint, or other image as desired.
#Text=The digital data from the imagers may then be combined in this process, for example, using the techniques of U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 6,249,616 and others.
#Text=As noted above in the present disclosure, the combined "image" may then be checked against a database to determine an identity of the person.
#Text=The augmented reality glasses may include such a database in the memory, or may refer the signals data elsewhere 6708 for comparison and checking.
#Text=[0685] A process for taking contactless fingerprints, palm prints or other biometric prints is disclosed in the flowchart of FIG. 68.
#Text=In one embodiment, a polarized light source is provided 6801.
#Text=In a second step 6802, the person of interest and the selected body part is positioned for illumination by the light.
#Text=In another embodiment, it may be possible to use incident white light rather than using a polarized light source.
#Text=When the image is ready to be taken, light is reflected 6803 from the person to two cameras or imagers.

#Text=A polarizing filter is placed in front of each of the two cameras, so that the light received by the cameras is polarized 6804 in two different planes, such as in a horizontal and vertical plane.
#Text=Each camera then detects 6805 the polarized light.
#Text=The cameras or other sensors then convert the incidence of light into signals or data 6806 suitable for preparation of images.
#Text=Finally, the images are then combined 6807 to form a very distinct, reliable print.
#Text=The result is an image of very high quality that may be compared to digital databases to identify the person and to detect persons of interest.
